title: 109_s2670
content: The Energy Fairness for America Act is the short title of this legislation, which amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The table of contents for this Act is provided. The Energy Fairness for America Act amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by terminating deductions and allowances related to oil and gas industries. This includes the termination of deductions for intangible drilling and development costs, percentage depletion allowance, enhanced oil recovery credit, and certain provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. Additionally, there are modifications to foreign tax credit rules and rules relating to foreign oil and gas income. The Energy Fairness for America Act terminates deductions for intangible drilling and development costs and percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The Energy Fairness for America Act terminates percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells and enhanced oil recovery credit for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The Energy Fairness for America Act terminates certain provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The Energy Fairness for America Act repeals several provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 related to oil and gas royalties, production incentives, and royalty relief for deep water production. It also terminates the Alaska Offshore Royalty Suspension. The Energy Fairness for America Act repeals provisions related to oil and gas royalties, production incentives, and royalty relief for deep water production. Amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act removes Alaska Offshore Royalty Suspension. Effective upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. TERMINATION OF CERTAIN TAX PROVISIONS OF THE ENERGY POLICY ACT OF 2005. The Energy Fairness for America Act amends various sections related to electric transmission property, equipment used in refining liquid fuels, natural gas distribution lines, and natural gas gathering lines. The amendments adjust dates for treatment as 15-year or 7-year property. The Energy Fairness for America Act amends sections related to oil depletion deduction, amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures, and sets the effective date for the amendments. SEC. 7. REVALUATION OF LIFO INVENTORIES OF LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. SEC. 7. REVALUATION OF LIFO INVENTORIES OF LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, applicable integrated oil companies must increase the value of historic LIFO inventories of petroleum products by a layer adjustment amount and decrease cost of goods sold accordingly. If the increases exceed cost of goods sold, gross income is increased by the excess amount. The term "layer adjustment amount" is defined for this purpose. The term "layer adjustment amount" refers to the product of $18.75 and the number of barrels of crude oil or barrel-of-oil equivalents in a historic LIFO layer. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined as per section 29(d)(5). Any required adjustment under this section does not constitute a change in accounting method, and there are no additions to tax for underpayments of estimated tax. No additions to tax under section 6655 for underpayments related to this section. An "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as having specific production and revenue criteria for the taxable year. For the taxable year ending in 2005, all persons considered a single employer under certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code will be treated as one entity. SEC. 8. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. Section 901 is amended to include special rules for dual capacity taxpayers regarding taxes paid to foreign countries or possessions of the United States. Amounts exceeding a certain limit may not be considered a tax if the foreign country or possession does not impose a generally applicable income tax. The special rules for dual capacity taxpayers under Section 901 pertain to taxes paid to foreign countries or possessions of the United States. These taxpayers are defined as individuals subject to levies in such countries. Amounts exceeding a specified limit may not be considered taxes if the foreign country does not impose a generally applicable income tax. The special rules for dual capacity taxpayers under Section 901 apply to individuals subject to levies in foreign countries or possessions of the United States. A generally applicable income tax is defined as an income tax imposed by a foreign country on income from conducting business within that country. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid in taxable years after the enactment date, except where contrary to US treaty obligations. SEC. 9. RULES RELATING TO FOREIGN OIL AND GAS INCOME. The provision amends section 904(d) to include foreign oil and gas income in the separate basket for foreign tax credit, both for years before 2007 and for years after 2006. The provision amends section 904(d) to include foreign oil and gas income in the separate basket for foreign tax credit, for years before 2007 and after 2006. The term 'foreign oil and gas income' is defined by section 954(g) and is not included in passive or general category income. Amendments are made to sections 904(d)(3)(F)(i), 907(a), 907(c)(4), and 907(f), with the changes applying to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by the Act apply to taxable years after December 31, 2006. Taxes paid or accrued before the Act's enactment related to foreign oil and gas income can be treated as such with proper documentation. The Act applies to taxable years after December 31, 2006. Taxes paid or accrued before the Act's enactment related to foreign oil and gas income can be treated as such with proper documentation. Unused oil and gas extraction taxes can be carried over to the taxpayer's first taxable year after the Act's enactment. The amendment does not apply to foreign oil and gas extraction losses from taxable years before the Act's enactment. Elimination of deferral for foreign oil and gas extraction income. The amendment defines foreign oil and gas income as income related to foreign oil and gas extraction or foreign oil-related income. Conforming amendments replace "base company oil related income" with "oil and gas income" in various sections. The amendment replaces references to "base company oil related income" with "oil and gas income" in various sections, effective for taxable years of foreign corporations beginning after the enactment of the Act.
